Legal_Issue: Is the RPD's decision regarding Chery's credibility reasonable under sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in dates, actions post-incident, failure to claim asylum in the U.S., political involvement, community work, fear of persecution
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Chery) must demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of corroborating evidence, failure to seek asylum in the U.S.
Legal_Rule: A person must demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion under IRPA sections 96 and 97
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider key evidence supporting political involvement and fear of persecution
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to political opinions and community work in Haiti
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined – original decision set aside
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RPD's assessment found unreasonable due to overlooked evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dates of incidents, political activities, travel to U.S., failure to claim asylum there, community leadership role
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Court_Result: Federal Court allowed the application and ordered redetermination by a new panel
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities / well-founded fear standard
Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration by a different RPD panel
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of RPD decision and referral for new hearing
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Fear of persecution based on political opinion
Applicable_Process: Refugee protection determination process, judicial review
